channel.title: Malabo on Srikanth Perinkulam
channel.description: Recent content in Malabo on Srikanth Perinkulam

item.title: 31 Dec 2025 10:30
item.description:
JAN | FEB | MAR | APR | MAY | JUN | JUL | AUG | SEP | OCT | NOV | DEC

JAN

  • We fit in a quick trip to Houston. Getting there and back was quite eventful!
  • Hiked La Malinche with the ESC boys and had a good taste of frostbite.
  • Work took me to Matamoros. Would be my last TDY while with ESC Mexico city!
  • M’s offer got rescinded because of the ‘Hiring freeze’…

FEB

  • Hiked Pico de Aguia sur yet again. Different route though.
  • Decided not to hike Orizaba. Could have checked this off the list had I planned this a bit better.
  • Bid adieu to the Mexico team!

MAR

  • ALL of this month was spent on our home-leave. NJ > Boston > Florida > Las Vegas > Utah/Arizona > Seattle > Vancouver > Baltimore
  • Highlight of this trip was visiting the slot canyons in Glen Canyon NRA. Oh and the skiing in Wachusett!

APR

  • Scheduled our consumables shipment for Yaounde.
  • PCS’d to Yaounde around mid April.
  • Six years ago, I walked out of WTW on April 1st. So glad I did!

MAY

  • Work trip to Malabo.
  • S still thinks it is a magical world!
  • Those Ceiba trees are magnificent!
  • Tourist for a day in Yaounde.

JUN

  • Took that armored cruiser for a spin.
  • Got tenured amidst news of RIFs…
  • Mummyjaan has that cardiac event and we get a taste of Cameroons abysmal medical system. Slowest four days of my recent past…

JUL

  • Our R&R turns into a Medevac to Dubai. Spent a few days with the Kulethas.
  • Fit in a whirlwind trip to Hyderabad, Ahmedabad, Trivandrum, Ernakulam, Bangalore and Madras.
  • S and I traveled together for a week. Our first without M!

AUG

  • Back to Malabo on another work trip.
  • Pushed the gas pedal on those IRAs.

SEP

  • Visited the Mefou primate sanctuary.
  • US begins it’s longest shutdown in history so far…

OCT

  • Furloughed for a day by mistake.
  • M&S visit london for a couple weeks and have a days’ layover on Istanbul.
  • This 92 year old head of state secures another seven year term.
  • Learnt something fun about watches.

NOV

  • Went to the 250th Marine ball.
  • Hiked up Mbankolo
  • M leaves for her LNA orientation.

DEC

  • Slowly falling into a rhythm solo-parenting S this month until her school break.
  • The Matha1’s made it to M’s flag-day!
  • S&I head to the U.S. for a couple weeks.
  • Skiing at Liberty. Just hit me that we did go skiing in Wachussett earlier this year in March!

And that’s a wrap! ðŸ”—

item.title: 09 Aug 2025 21:30
item.description:
Amazed at how well this ‘Paseo’ is maintained! We were here in the morning on a weekend and there was barely anybody here. Word is also that this area is not really frequented by locals. Not even during the evenings. Wonder why though? This country’s got SO MUCH potential. The infrastructure is really good. Would be barely surprised if all of this is managed by a Chinese contracted firm. Definitely something to say about the merits of foreign influence.

ðŸ”—

Not even during the evenings. Wonder why though? This country’s got SO MUCH potential. The infrastructure is really good. Would be barely surprised if all of this is managed by a Chinese contracted firm. Definitely something to say about the merits of foreign influence.

ðŸ”—

item.title: 15 May 2025 21:30
item.description:
Back from a work trip in Malabo. Got there last Thursday and worked through the weekend. We completed a minor site upgrade and completed almost all of the planned work.

Didn’t quite get to explore any of the island since we were mostly shuttling back and forth from work. From what little I did get to see though, this place is beautiful. Between China’s belt and road initiative and the island’s oil money from the 90s, Infrastructure looked to be quite top notch. The airport terminal is quite spiffy.

Food was mediocre at best. The Magno hotel has a decent restaurant. Next time I’m here I should probably come over the weekend to explore the cafe’s and the boardwalk a bit.

The ~230 Ft towering Ceiba tree in the embassy compound is a terrific sight. Apparently this tree is quite prevalent all across Africa.

Internet in the hotel was barely functional - for call’s atleast. Looks like some port-blocking was definitely at play. Not having those daily calls back home maybe also made the trip feel a bit longer that it actually was? Need to go better prepared next time! ðŸ”—
item.content:encoded:
Back from a work trip in Malabo. Got there last Thursday and worked through the weekend. We completed a minor site upgrade and completed almost all of the planned work.

Didn’t quite get to explore any of the island since we were mostly shuttling back and forth from work. From what little I did get to see though, this place is beautiful. Between China’s belt and road initiative and the island’s oil money from the 90s, Infrastructure looked to be quite top notch. The airport terminal is quite spiffy.

Food was mediocre at best. The Magno hotel has a decent restaurant. Next time I’m here I should probably come over the weekend to explore the cafe’s and the boardwalk a bit.

The ~230 Ft towering Ceiba tree in the embassy compound is a terrific sight. Apparently this tree is quite prevalent all across Africa.

Internet in the hotel was barely functional - for call’s atleast. Looks like some port-blocking was definitely at play. Not having those daily calls back home maybe also made the trip feel a bit longer that it actually was? Need to go better prepared next time! ðŸ”—
